column1: This pre-capstone course uses a ‘writing-to-learn’ approach that guides student step-by-step through the making of a primary research article in the life science discipline. The course introduces students to the process of problem solving in science through the scientific method of inquiry. The underlying principles of commonly used life-science methodologies for conducting research will be introduced through lectures while practical training in literature survey, information gathering, and data analysis will be provided through hands-on experience. The course will also introduce techniques in scientific communications by guiding students through each stage of the writing process and by conducting oral presentations, group discussion and peer reviews.

The course provides the opportunity for students to earn University Credits (2 units) from one summer research internship in an academic or industrial setting. During the internship, students should be undertaking a CMB-related research project in an established laboratory with a time commitment of at least 160 hours. Internship work can be arranged either within or outside the university (can be overseas too).

This laboratory course provides the practical experience in techniques of molecular biology and cell culturing. Project-based experimental projects are designed to guide students through the investigative process of scientific research. Molecular biology work includes the construction of the recombinant DNA clones tagged with fluorescent proteins (FPs) as well as the generation, characterization and purification of the encoded FP-tagged fusion proteins. In addition, the training in aseptic cell culturing techniques to handle E. coli, plant and mammalian cell lines is provided for the skill preparation of the subsequent transient expression, establishment of transgenic plants and cell lines carrying the previously constructed recombinant DNA clones.Students’ progress will be evaluated through records of data analysis and evaluation in experimental logbooks, laboratory write-up and a final lab report in addition to quizzes and exams at term’s end. Students will also be divided into groups to produce a science video illustrating a Cell and Molecular Biology related topic of their own interests. Students are expected to demonstrate team-spirit through division of labor in the project as well as to learn and communicate science through self-motivated pursuit of knowledge.

This laboratory course is a continuation of CMBI3010 Cell and Molecular Biology Laboratory I. This laboratory course provides practical experience in the studies of cell biology. Project-based experimental projects are designed to guide students through the investigative process of scientific research. Different from traditional lab courses, which consist of separate and unrelated exercises, this CMB lab course is offered as term-long projects with all techniques or experimental methods incorporated into each project. Students will therefore not only learn various modern techniques, but also how and when these techniques are applied in life science research. In addition to the transgenic plant cell lines established in CMBI3010, this course will introduce students to transient expressions in animal cell models. Cell imaging approach employing high-end methodologies in microscopy to detect the expression and sub-cellular localization of fluorescent proteins as well as organelle dynamics will be used. Hands-on experience on conventional experimental methods including protein purification, Western blotting analysis and other common in-vivo or in-vitro cellular assays will also be provided.

This laboratory course provides the hands-on experience in various advanced microscopies that are commonly employed in cell biology research. Students first get familiar with the operation of the high-end microscopes in the laboratory. Subsequently, using the microscopes, students validate the materials established in CMBI3010, which will be used in CMBI3020 and CMBI3040.

This laboratory course provides the hands-on experience in the advanced techniques in cell and molecular biology research. The techniques include reporter gene assay, co-immunoprecipitation, real time polymerase chain reaction, and Forster resonance energy transfer. With the materials established and knowledge gained in CMBI3010, 3020 and 3030, students make use of these advanced techniques to explore new aspects in cell and molecular biology research.

This course provides intensive training on literature reading and analysis in cell and molecular biology. Following CMBI2200, the first STOT course offered, a group of students are assigned to individual teachers for more direct and closer supervision. Students choose and work on the subjects of their interest, and the project involves intensive literature reading and discussions with the supervisor. Students are required to identify major questions or problems in cell and molecular biology fields. A literature review and an oral presentation for the identified questions or problems are assessed at term end.

This course provides an overview on the phylogeny and basic biology of selected top model organisms including mouse, zebrafish, fruit-fly, Caenorhabditis elegans, Arabidopsis thaliana, and yeast. Due to their biological and technical advantages, these model organisms have been extensively employed for discovering a series of fundamental biological questions in the research of the modern life sciences. The course is instructed by our faculty members and invited speakers from other universities who use these models extensively in their researches.

This course is the continuation of its pre-requisite CMBI3100. Regarding the questions addressed in CMBI3100, students learn how to prepare a research proposal under supervision by the same teacher. In addition to the scientific writing and oral communication, the main focus is on the proposal writing, including question identification, idea/hypothesis formulation, organization, and language usage. Performance is evaluated by the proposal and an oral defense at term end.

This course covers the general principles of and current developments in protein trafficking for both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Specific topics include the structures and functions of transport vesicles, receptor-mediated protein transport, protein compartmentation in the secretory and endocytic pathways as well as in other organelles, protein degradation and the biological consequences of protein mis-localization in organisms. Students are required to watch online Lecture Videos in KEEP or Blackboard about Basic Knowledge in protein trafficking prior to the Lectures. These online Lecture Videos are supplemented with online quizzes in which students need to finish after watching these videos. In addition, students will also watch videos discussing recent Research Papers. During lectures, students will have in-depth discussion regarding the questions, key concepts and up-to-date research. By these means students will be able to clarify their concepts and be familiar with the latest research findings that are related to protein trafficking. Students will also learn the current developments of protein trafficking in details by delivering a presentation on a relevant topic derived from a recent research paper, with a Q&A session. The presentation will be graded by both Professor and peer students.Blended-mode class section is available for this course. Please refer to the “Class Notes” of the blended-mode class section for details.

This course covers the energetics of protein folding including hydrophobic effect, hydrogen bond, electrostatic interactions, and conformational entropy, and how these factors interplay in protein folding and functions. Through detailed in-class discussion on the classic and the latest research literatures, students will learn how important theories and hypotheses of protein folding energetics were formulated, supported or disproved by experiments. The students will also learn how to apply the theories to improve protein stability in protein design and engineering through a group project.

This course covers the general principles, concepts and moderntechnologies in signal transduction for both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Specific topics include signal perception by different receptors, phosphorylation-mediated signaling, signaling crosstalk, and methodologies in signal transduction research.

This advanced cell biology course provides a comprehensive review on current issues on cancer cell biology such as the molecular mechanisms of cancer pathogenesis, cancer cell proliferation and differentiation, programmed cell death (apoptosis), cell migration (metastasis), and the current technologies for cancer diagnosis and therapy.

This advanced cell biology course introduces basic cellular and molecular features of pluripotent stem cells and provides a comprehensive review on current important issues in stem cell research and regenerative medicine.

This advanced cell biology course focuses on the basic functional units and development of the mammalian nervous systems. Special cellular and molecular features of neurons are also discussed. Other topics include neuronal polarity, membrane trafficking, axonal transport, axon guidance, synapse formation and synaptic plasticity.

This advanced molecular biology course introduces the latest research focuses on genomics and transcriptomics. It covers the sequencing and mapping of the entire genome, methodologies in RNA gene expression profiling, structure and function of genes as well as regulation and dynamics of the transcriptome in an organism.

This advanced molecular biology course introduces the principles and methods of proteomics, the high-throughput investigation of proteins. In particular, the structural and functional relationships between proteins are discussed. The course provides students a global view of protein components involved in important biological pathways of living cells. Common web-based tools for protein sequence annotation, protein structure prediction and protein structure analysis are covered. Besides, advances in methodologies for discussion include the two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2DE), liquid chromatography (LC), mass spectrometry and high throughput x-ray crystallography.

This advanced molecular biology course aims to familiarize students with the latest research focuses in metabolomics, which concerns data acquisition and quantitative characterization of metabolites and metabolic pathways in living organisms. Modern technologies in profiling and identifying metabolites are introduced, and recent applications of metabolomics in various aspects of biology are also discussed.

This is an advanced course in understanding the current topics and the most up-to-date developments in cell biology research, through problem-based discussion using several recent and significant research papers preferably from different top-ranked international journals. Specific topics include protein targeting and its targeted disease, protein trafficking and biotechnology, organelle dynamics and biogenesis, stem cell development in therapy and antibody engineering.

This is an advanced course in understanding the current topics and the most up-to-date developments in the research on molecular biology, through problem-based discussion using several recent and significant research papers preferably from different top-ranked international journals. Specific topics for discussion include the technology and development of current DNA sequencing and cloning, transformation and transgenic technology as well as the molecular mechanisms of the developmental regulation.

This is an advanced course in understanding the current topics and the most up-to-date developments in biotechniques for cell and molecular biology research, through problem-based discussion using several recent and significant research papers preferably from different top-ranked international journals. Specific topics for discussion include the development and application of fluorescent technology and cell imaging, nanotechnology for biosciences, MS technology for proteomics, metabolomics and genomics.

In this course, students carry out an independent laboratory research project either provided by the supervisor or jointly decided with the student. To fulfill the course requirement, students are required to discuss their progresses with their supervisors regularly and submit a research proposal.

In this course, students carry out an independent laboratory research project either provided by the supervisor or jointly decided with the student. Students are required to discuss their progresses with their supervisors regularly and submit a progress report at the end of the term. For students who will not enroll in CMBI4903, a final report in the form of a manuscript and an oral presentation are assessed at the end of term for performance.

In this course, students continue to work on and finish up the research project from CMBI4902. Relevant data analysis and conclusion formulation are performed after discussion with supervisors. A final report in the form of a manuscript and an oral presentation are assessed at the end of term for performance.
